verses.arabic: وَإِذْ وَٰعَدْنَا مُوسَىٰٓ أَرْبَعِينَ لَيْلَةً ثُمَّ ٱتَّخَذْتُمُ ٱلْعِجْلَ مِنۢ بَعْدِهِۦ وَأَنتُمْ ظَٰلِمُونَ
verses.transliteration: Wa idh wā'adnā Mūsā arba'īna laylatan thumma attakhadhtumu al-'ijla min ba'dihi wa antum ẓālimūn
verses.translation: And when We appointed for Moses forty nights, then you took the calf after him while you were wrongdoers

grammar.function: Connects this story to previous narratives
grammar.reason: Links this reminder about Moses to the previous favors mentioned. Shows continuity in the historical narrative of Allah's blessings to the Children of Israel.
grammar.practical: The simple conjunction 'and'. In the Quran, it often introduces a new scene or story while connecting it to what came before. When Allah says 'wa idh' (and when/remember when), He's calling attention to an important historical event that carries lessons.

grammar.function: Refers to a specific time in the past
grammar.reason: Points to a particular historical moment - when Moses was called for forty nights. Often used in the Quran to recall important events.
grammar.practical: 'Idh' means 'when' but specifically for past events. It's like saying 'Remember that time when...' When you see 'idh' in the Quran, expect a flashback to an important historical lesson. The combination 'wa idh' appears frequently: 'And remember when...' - calling us to reflect on past events.

words.translation: We appointed / We made an appointment with

grammar.root: و-ع-د (w-'-d) - to promise, to appoint, to make an appointment
grammar.reason: Form III indicates mutual action - a meeting or appointment between two parties. The 'nā' suffix shows Allah is the speaker (the royal 'We').
grammar.practical: From the root wa'ada (to promise). In Form III (wā'ada), it means to make an appointment with someone or arrange a meeting. 'Wā'adnā' = 'We appointed/We made an appointment'. The 'nā' at the end means 'We' (Allah speaking). This refers to Allah calling Moses to Mount Sinai for forty nights to receive the Torah. Notice how the verb includes both the action and the doer in one word!

grammar.case: Accusative (manṣūb) - but doesn't show case ending
grammar.reason: Direct object of the verb 'appointed'. Foreign names ending in alif maqṣūrah (ى) don't show case endings. Moses is the one Allah appointed.
grammar.practical: The Arabic name for Moses (Musa in Hebrew). This name appears 136 times in the Quran - more than any other prophet! Notice it ends with alif maqṣūrah (ى) which looks like 'ya' but is pronounced 'a'. Names like this don't change their endings based on grammar cases - they always look the same. The small alif above (ٰٓ) helps clarify the pronunciation.

grammar.function: Adverb of time - how long the appointment was
grammar.reason: Numbers from 11-99 in Arabic take accusative case. The 'īna' ending indicates accusative. This specifies the duration of the appointment.
grammar.practical: Means 'forty'. Comes from arba'a (four), but in the tens format. Numbers 11-99 always end in 'īna' when in accusative case. Here it describes how many nights - forty nights. This refers to when Moses went to Mount Sinai and stayed forty nights to receive revelation. In Arabic, when you count things, you put the number first, then what you're counting.

grammar.reason: After numbers (except 1 and 2), the counted noun is singular in accusative case with tanwīn. This is a unique Arabic grammar rule called tamyīz.
grammar.practical: Means 'night' (single). From 'layl' (night). Even though we're talking about forty nights, Arabic uses SINGULAR after numbers 3-99! So it's literally 'forty night' not 'forty nights' in Arabic grammar. The 'an' ending (tanwīn) is required after numbers. This is called tamyīz (specification) - it specifies what you're counting. Strange rule, but that's how Arabic works with numbers!

grammar.function: Indicates sequence with a time gap
grammar.reason: Shows what happened AFTER the forty nights - with a pause or delay. Different from 'fa' which means immediate sequence.
grammar.practical: 'Thumma' means 'then' but specifically with a time gap - 'and THEN, after a while...' It's different from 'fa' which means immediate 'then'. Here it emphasizes: First Moses went for forty nights, THEN (during his absence) the people did something terrible. The pause in 'thumma' makes their betrayal even more shocking - they waited until he was gone!

grammar.reason: Form VIII indicates reflexive or intensive action. The 'tumu' suffix addresses the Children of Israel directly - 'YOU did this'. The doubling of the 't' (ٱتَّ) is characteristic of Form VIII.
grammar.practical: From 'akhada' (to take). In Form VIII (ittakhada), it means to take something for yourself, to adopt, or to make something your own. 'Attakhadhtumu' = 'you (plural) took/adopted'. The 'tumu' ending directly addresses a group: 'YOU people did this!' Notice the dramatic shift - Allah was making an appointment with Moses (third person), but now suddenly addresses them directly in second person - this direct address makes it more powerful and accusatory!

grammar.root: ع-ج-ل ('-j-l) - related to calf, or haste
grammar.reason: Direct object of the verb 'took'. They took the calf (as an object of worship). The fatha ending shows it's receiving the action of the verb.
grammar.practical: Means 'the calf' - specifically the golden calf that the Israelites made as an idol. The root '-j-l relates to calves but also to hastiness (they hastily made this idol while Moses was gone). The 'al' makes it 'THE calf' - the infamous one. The 'a' ending (fatha) shows this is WHAT they took - it's the object. Remember: object of verb = fatha ending. This is one of the most tragic moments in their history - worshipping a man-made statue!

grammar.function: Indicates time - after, or separation - from
grammar.reason: Shows when this happened - AFTER his departure. Can mean 'from' in the sense of 'following' a point in time.
grammar.practical: 'Min' usually means 'from' but here it means 'after' - indicating time. They took the calf as an idol AFTER he left, FROM the time he departed. Prepositions in Arabic are very flexible in meaning. The small sign (ۢ) under the 'n' is a sukūn, showing no vowel sound after the letter.

grammar.root: ب-ع-د (b-'-d) - to be distant, to be after
grammar.case: Genitive (majrūr) - ends in 'i' due to preposition 'min'
grammar.reason: The preposition 'min' requires genitive case. The 'hi' pronoun refers to Moses. Together: 'after him' - after Moses left.
grammar.practical: 'Ba'd' means 'after' or 'distance'. 'Hi' means 'him' (referring to Moses). Together: 'ba'dihi' = 'after him'. The 'i' ending shows it comes after a preposition (min). So 'min ba'dihi' = 'after him' or 'following his departure'. The small circle with the ـۦ is another way to write the pronoun 'hi'. This phrase emphasizes the betrayal - Moses wasn't even gone long, and they already turned to idol worship!

grammar.reason: This 'wa' introduces the state they were in while taking the calf - they were wrongdoers. It emphasizes they knew it was wrong even as they did it.
grammar.practical: Here 'wa' means 'while' - introducing their STATE or condition. Not just connecting two things, but describing their condition during the action: 'You took the calf WHILE you were wrongdoers' - meaning you KNEW it was wrong! This type of 'wa' in Arabic grammar is called ḥāl (circumstantial), describing the circumstances of an action.

grammar.reason: Emphasizes the subject - YOU yourselves. Makes the accusation more direct and personal. This is the subject of 'you were wrongdoers'.
grammar.practical: 'Antum' = 'you' (plural, for a group of men or mixed group). This pronoun emphasizes the subject strongly. It's like saying 'YOU - yes, YOU people!' Making it crystal clear who is being addressed. Used here to stress their responsibility: YOU YOURSELVES were the wrongdoers. Can't blame anyone else!

grammar.root: ظ-ل-م (ẓ-l-m) - to wrong, to oppress, to do injustice
grammar.reason: Predicate (khabar) describing their state. The 'ūna' ending indicates nominative plural. Describes what they WERE - active wrongdoers.
grammar.practical: From 'ẓalama' (to wrong/oppress). The pattern 'fā'il' makes it an active participle - someone actively doing the action. 'Ẓālim' = wrongdoer/oppressor (one who does ẓulm). The 'ūna' ending makes it plural masculine: wrongdoers. The beautiful/terrible thing about this word: ẓulm literally means putting something in the wrong place. Worshipping a calf instead of Allah? That's the ultimate ẓulm - putting worship in completely the wrong place! The ūna ending shows this is the predicate (what they ARE).

verses.arabic: ثُمَّ عَفَوْنَا عَنكُم مِّنۢ بَعْدِ ذَٰلِكَ لَعَلَّكُمْ تَشْكُرُونَ
verses.transliteration: Thumma 'afawnā 'ankum min ba'di dhālika la'allakum tashkurūn
verses.translation: Then We forgave you after that so perhaps you would be grateful

grammar.reason: Indicates what happened after their terrible sin - Allah's mercy came THEN, after a delay. Shows sequence of events.
grammar.practical: 'Thumma' again - meaning 'then' with a gap in time. First they sinned with the golden calf, THEN (after some time and consequences) Allah forgave them. The time gap here is significant - they had to face consequences first, then forgiveness came. Allah's mercy, even after such a great sin!

grammar.root: ع-ف-و ('-f-w) - to pardon, to forgive, to erase
grammar.reason: Simple past tense showing Allah's completed act of forgiveness. The 'nā' suffix shows Allah (We) is the one who forgave.
grammar.practical: From ''afā' (to pardon/forgive). ''Afawnā' = 'We forgave/pardoned'. The root '-f-w carries the meaning of erasing, wiping away - like completely removing the sin! The 'nā' ending means 'We' (Allah). Beautiful word showing complete forgiveness. In fact, one of Allah's names is Al-'Afuww (The Pardoner) - the One who completely erases sins. This verb shows the magnitude of Allah's mercy - even after idol worship, He forgave them!

grammar.reason: Shows who was forgiven - you (the Children of Israel). The preposition ''an' with ''afā' creates the meaning of 'to forgive/pardon someone'.
grammar.practical: ''An' means 'from' or 'about'. 'Kum' means 'you' (plural). Together: ''ankum' = 'from you' or 'you'. The combination ''afawnā 'ankum' is the Arabic way to say 'We forgave you'. In Arabic, you 'pardon FROM someone' (forgive from you) rather than 'forgive you' directly. The 'kum' clearly addresses the group of Children of Israel who worshipped the calf.

grammar.reason: Shows when the forgiveness came - AFTER that event. Temporal meaning of 'min'.
grammar.practical: 'Min' meaning 'from' in the sense of time - 'from that point onward' or simply 'after'. The small mark (ۢ) is sukūn showing no vowel. Notice the shadda (ّ) combining with the mīm - this is just a writing convention in the Quran showing where words connect.

grammar.reason: The preposition 'min' makes this genitive. It's an adverb showing WHEN - after that event.
grammar.practical: 'Ba'd' means 'after'. The 'i' ending shows it follows a preposition (min). Used with time to mean 'after' or 'following'. This creates emphasis: 'from after that' = even after such a terrible sin, forgiveness came!

grammar.reason: Points back to the sin of the golden calf. In a genitive construct (iḍāfah) with 'ba'd'.
grammar.practical: 'Dhālika' = 'that', pointing to what just happened - the worship of the calf. 'Min ba'di dhālika' = 'after that' or 'following that event'. Used to reference something already mentioned. The demonstrative makes it emphatic: after THAT terrible thing you did, We still forgave you!

words.translation: So that you may / Perhaps you / In order that you

grammar.type: Harf + Ism - Particle of Hope + Pronoun
grammar.reason: Shows the PURPOSE of forgiveness - so that you would be grateful. 'La'alla' always takes a pronoun suffix and is followed by a verb showing the hoped-for result.
grammar.practical: 'La'alla' is a beautiful particle meaning 'perhaps', 'hopefully', or 'so that'. 'Kum' = 'you (plural)'. Together: 'la'allakum' = 'so that you' or 'perhaps you'. This shows Allah's purpose in forgiving them - hoping they would respond with gratitude! It's like saying: 'We forgave you in the hope that you would be thankful'. Every blessing from Allah comes with this implicit hope that we'll be grateful!

words.translation: You are grateful / You give thanks

grammar.root: ش-ك-ر (sh-k-r) - to be grateful, to give thanks
grammar.reason: Describes the hoped-for ongoing state - that you would be continually grateful. The 'ta' prefix indicates second person (you), and 'ūna' ending shows plural.
grammar.practical: From 'shakara' (to be grateful/to thank). 'Tashkurūna' = 'you (plural) are grateful' or 'you give thanks'. The pattern: 'ta' at beginning + 'ūna' at end = 'YOU (plural) do' something. So this is: 'YOU give thanks'. From the root sh-k-r which means gratitude - recognizing blessings and acting accordingly. The verse shows cause and effect: Allah forgave you SO THAT you would be grateful. Gratitude is what Allah expects after His mercy!

verses.arabic: وَإِذْ ءَاتَيْنَا مُوسَى ٱلْكِتَٰبَ وَٱلْفُرْقَانَ لَعَلَّكُمْ تَهْتَدُونَ
verses.transliteration: Wa idh ātaynā Mūsā al-kitāba wal-furqāna la'allakum tahtadūn
verses.translation: And when We gave Moses the Scripture and the Criterion so that you might be guided

grammar.reason: Continues the list of favors Allah gave to the Children of Israel.
grammar.practical: 'Wa' = 'and'. Connecting this blessing to all the previous ones mentioned. Allah is listing favor after favor to remind them of His bounties.

grammar.function: Points to specific time in past
grammar.reason: Recalls another specific historical moment - when Moses received the Scripture.
grammar.practical: 'Idh' = 'when' (for past events). 'Wa idh' = 'And remember when'. Another flashback to an important moment in their history.

grammar.root: أ-ت-ي (a-t-y) - to come, to bring, to give
grammar.reason: Form IV of 'atā means to give or grant something. The 'nā' suffix shows Allah is the giver.
grammar.practical: From 'atā' (to come/bring). In Form IV: 'ātā' means 'to give' or 'to grant'. 'Ātaynā' = 'We gave'. The 'nā' ending = 'We' (Allah). One of the most beautiful verbs for giving - when Allah GRANTS something. Notice the hamza (ء) at the beginning - pronounced as a glottal stop.

grammar.reason: The one who received the Scripture - indirect object of 'gave'.
grammar.practical: Moses (Musa) - the recipient of the Torah. Indirect object: We gave TO Moses. As before, this name doesn't show case endings due to the alif maqṣūrah (ى) ending.

grammar.reason: Direct object - what was given. The 'a' ending shows accusative case.
grammar.practical: 'Al-kitāb' = 'the Book', specifically the Torah given to Moses. The 'a' ending (fatha) shows this is WHAT was given - the direct object. From k-t-b (to write). The small alif (ٰ) above shows the long 'ā' sound.
'And' - connecting the Book with the Criterion. Both were given together.

words.translation: The Criterion / The Standard of right and wrong

grammar.reason: Second direct object - another thing that was given. Same case as 'the Book'.
grammar.practical: 'Al-furqān' = 'the Criterion' or 'the Standard'. From 'faraqa' (to separate/distinguish). Al-Furqān is something that SEPARATES truth from falsehood, right from wrong, guidance from misguidance. This refers to the revelation given to Moses that clearly distinguished between truth and falsehood. The Quran itself is also called Al-Furqān! The 'a' ending shows it's also an object of 'gave'.

words.translation: So that you may / Perhaps you

grammar.type: Harf + Ism - Particle of Hope + Pronoun
grammar.reason: Shows the PURPOSE of giving the Scripture - so they would be guided.
grammar.practical: 'La'allakum' = 'so that you' or 'perhaps you'. Same word we saw before. Shows Allah's purpose in giving them the Book - hoping they would use it for guidance!

words.translation: You are guided / You find guidance

grammar.root: ه-د-ي (h-d-y) - to guide, to be guided
grammar.reason: Form VIII here means to be guided or to guide oneself. The hoped-for result of receiving the Book.
grammar.practical: From 'hadā' (to guide). In Form VIII: 'ihtadā' means to be guided or to find guidance for oneself. 'Tahtadūna' = 'you (plural) are guided' or 'you find guidance'. The 'ta' at start + 'ūna' at end = 'you (plural) do'. The 't' before 'h' (تَهْتَ) is the characteristic of Form VIII. Beautiful meaning: We gave you the Book SO THAT you would find your way to guidance!

verses.arabic: وَإِذْ قَالَ مُوسَىٰ لِقَوْمِهِۦ يَٰقَوْمِ إِنَّكُمْ ظَلَمْتُمْ أَنفُسَكُم بِٱتِّخَاذِكُمُ ٱلْعِجْلَ فَتُوبُوٓا۟ إِلَىٰ بَارِئِكُمْ فَٱقْتُلُوٓا۟ أَنفُسَكُمْ ذَٰلِكُمْ خَيْرٌ لَّكُمْ عِندَ بَارِئِكُمْ فَتَابَ عَلَيْكُمْ ۚ إِنَّهُۥ هُوَ ٱلتَّوَّابُ ٱلرَّحِيمُ
verses.transliteration: Wa idh qāla Mūsā liqawmihi yā qawmi innakum ẓalamtum anfusakum bittikhādhikumu al-'ijla fatūbū ilā bāri'ikum faqtulū anfusakum dhālikum khayrun lakum 'inda bāri'ikum fatāba 'alaykum innahu huwa at-tawwābu ar-raḥīm
verses.translation: And when Moses said to his people, 'O my people, indeed you have wronged yourselves by taking the calf, so turn in repentance to your Creator and kill yourselves. That is best for you in the sight of your Creator.' Then He accepted your repentance; indeed, He is the Accepting of repentance, the Merciful

grammar.practical: 'And' - continuing the narrative
'When' - another moment in history being recalled

grammar.reason: Simple past tense verb - Moses said.
grammar.practical: From 'qāla' (to say). 'Qāla' = 'he said'. One of the most common verbs in the Quran, appearing hundreds of times. Introduces what Moses said to his people.

grammar.reason: Moses is the one who said - the subject/doer of the action.
grammar.practical: Moses - the speaker, the subject of 'said'.

grammar.reason: Shows WHO he spoke to - his people. The 'hi' pronoun makes it possessive.
grammar.practical: 'Li' = 'to'. 'Qawm' = 'people/nation/tribe'. 'Hi' = 'his'. Together: 'liqawmihi' = 'to his people'. The root q-w-m is the same as in 'qāma' (to stand) - a people are those who 'stand together'. The 'i' endings show genitive case (after preposition li, and in possessive construct with hi).

grammar.reason: Vocative - calling attention. The 'i' at the end represents the possessive 'my'.
grammar.practical: 'Yā' is the vocative particle = 'O!' used when calling someone. 'Qawmi' = 'my people'. Together: 'Yā qawmi' = 'O my people!' A common way prophets address their people. The 'yā' makes it a direct call, and the 'i' at the end shows possession (my people). The long mark (ٰ) over ya emphasizes the call.

grammar.reason: 'Inna' is one of the emphatic particles that makes statements definite and certain. It requires the following noun/pronoun to be in accusative case.
grammar.practical: 'Inna' = 'indeed/verily/truly'. 'Kum' = 'you (plural)'. Together: 'innakum' = 'indeed you' or 'verily you'. This particle adds strong emphasis - there's no doubt about what follows! Moses is being very direct: INDEED you have done wrong. 'Inna' is one of the sisters of inna (أخوات إن) that emphasize statements.

grammar.reason: Accusation of what they did. The 'tum' suffix directly addresses them as the doers.
grammar.practical: From 'ẓalama' (to wrong/oppress). 'Ẓalamtum' = 'you (plural) wronged/oppressed'. The 'tum' ending means 'you (plural) did it'. Direct accusation from Moses: YOU wronged! Remember, ẓulm means putting something in the wrong place - the ultimate wrongdoing.

grammar.reason: Direct object of 'wronged'. They wronged their own selves. The possessive 'kum' makes it 'your selves'.
grammar.practical: 'Nafs' means 'self/soul'. 'Anfus' is the plural = 'selves'. 'Kum' = 'your'. Together: 'anfusakum' = 'yourselves/your own selves'. Beautiful construction showing they harmed themselves! Sin doesn't hurt Allah - it hurts the sinner. By worshipping the calf, they wronged their OWN souls.

grammar.type: Harf + Ism - Preposition + Verbal Noun (Maṣdar) + Pronoun
grammar.reason: Explains HOW they wronged themselves - by taking/adopting. The 'bi' shows the means or cause.
grammar.practical: 'Bi' = 'by/with' (shows the means). 'Ittikhādh' is the verbal noun (maṣdar) of Form VIII 'ittakhada' (to take/adopt) - meaning 'the taking' or 'the adopting'. 'Kum' = 'your'. Together: 'bittikhādhikumu' = 'by your taking/adopting'. This explains the METHOD of their wrongdoing. Notice the doubling of 't' (ٱتِّ) characteristic of Form VIII!

grammar.reason: Object of the verbal noun 'taking' - what they took/adopted.
grammar.practical: 'The calf' - the golden calf. Object of the verbal noun: 'your taking OF the calf'. The infamous idol they made.

grammar.type: Harf + Fi'l - Conjunction + Command Verb (Fi'l Amr)
grammar.reason: 'Fa' shows consequence or result. The command form tells them what to do now. The 'ū' ending indicates plural command.
grammar.practical: 'Fa' = 'so/then' (showing consequence). 'Tūbū' = 'repent!' or 'turn back!' (command to a group). From 'tāba' (to repent/return). The root t-w-b means to return or turn back - repentance is RETURNING to Allah! The command form with 'ū' at the end addresses multiple people: 'You all - REPENT!' The small zero-like symbol (۟) is just a Quranic mark showing the end of the word.

grammar.function: Indicates direction - to whom to return
grammar.reason: Shows the direction of repentance - TO your Creator.
grammar.practical: 'Ilā' = 'to/toward' - indicates direction or destination. Return TO whom? To your Creator! Shows repentance isn't just feeling sorry - it's RETURNING to Allah.

grammar.reason: The One they should return to. The 'kum' makes it possessive - YOUR Creator. Form of fā'il pattern shows the active doer.
grammar.practical: 'Bāri'' = 'Creator/Originator'. From 'bara'a' (to create/originate). This is a beautiful name of Allah - Al-Bāri' (The Originator) who creates from nothing. 'Kum' = 'your'. Together: 'bāri'ikum' = 'your Creator'. The 'i' ending shows genitive (after preposition ilā). Moses reminds them: repent to the One who CREATED you! How could you worship something you made yourself when your own Creator is right there?

grammar.reason: Another command - the severe consequence required for their sin. The 'fa' shows sequence: first repent, THEN kill.
grammar.practical: 'Fa' = 'so/then'. 'Uqtulū' = 'kill!' (command to plural). From 'qatala' (to kill). This is a shocking command but was the required atonement for idol worship. The 'ū' ending indicates plural command. According to scholars, this meant those who didn't worship the calf should execute those who did - a severe punishment showing the gravity of shirk (associating partners with Allah).

grammar.reason: Direct object of 'kill'. Can mean 'yourselves' or 'each other' - the innocent killing the guilty among them.
grammar.practical: 'Anfusakum' = 'yourselves' or 'each other'. Same word we saw before. Here it means the community had to execute the idol worshippers among themselves. A painful but necessary purification.

grammar.reason: Points to the command just given - THAT action (the killing). The 'kum' emphasizes it's directed at them.
grammar.practical: 'Dhālika' = 'that'. 'Kum' = 'your' (for you). Together: 'dhālikum' = 'that (for you)'. Points to what was just commanded: THAT action, that repentance and execution.

grammar.reason: Predicate describing 'that' - that is better/best. The tanwīn adds emphasis.
grammar.practical: 'Khayr' means 'good/better/best'. The 'un' ending (tanwīn) makes it nominative and indefinite. 'Khayrun' = 'better' or 'best'. This is the comparative/superlative form. Moses assures them: as hard as this is, it's BETTER for you than living with the sin of shirk!
'Li' = 'for'. 'Kum' = 'you'. Together: 'lakum' = 'for you'. This repentance and atonement is BETTER FOR YOU.

words.translation: With / In the sight of / Before

grammar.reason: Indicates WHERE it's better - in the sight of, with, before your Creator.
grammar.practical: ''Inda' = 'with/at/in the sight of/before'. Often used to mean 'in the judgment of' or 'with'. Better FOR you in the SIGHT of your Creator - meaning in Allah's judgment, this is what's best.
'Your Creator' - repeated again for emphasis. Better in the sight of the One who created you and knows what's truly best for you.

words.translation: So He accepted repentance / So He turned

grammar.type: Harf + Fi'l - Conjunction + Past Tense Verb
grammar.root: ت-و-ب (t-w-b) - to turn back, to accept repentance
grammar.reason: Shows what happened after they obeyed - Allah accepted their repentance. The 'fa' shows consequence.
grammar.practical: 'Fa' = 'so/then'. 'Tāba' = 'He turned/accepted repentance'. Same root as 'tūbū' (repent). When people turn TO Allah (tawbah), Allah turns TO them (accepting). 'Fatāba' = 'so He accepted' or 'so He turned (in mercy)'. Beautiful cycle: they repented, SO Allah accepted!

grammar.reason: Shows WHO Allah turned to in mercy - you (the Children of Israel).
grammar.practical: ''Alā' = 'upon/to'. 'Kum' = 'you'. Together: ''alaykum' = 'upon you' or 'to you'. The phrase 'tāba 'alā' means to turn in mercy toward, to accept someone's repentance. So 'tāba 'alaykum' = 'He accepted your repentance' or 'He turned to you in mercy'.
'Inna' = 'indeed/verily'. 'Hu' = 'He' (Allah). Together: 'innahu' = 'indeed He'. Strong emphasis about Allah's attributes that follow.

grammar.reason: Emphasizes that HE specifically, Allah alone, has these attributes.
grammar.practical: 'Huwa' = 'He'. Used here for extra emphasis: 'Indeed He - HE is...' Double emphasis with both 'innahu' and 'huwa'! Making it absolutely clear: HE (Allah) is the One with these qualities.

words.translation: The Oft-Returning (in mercy) / The Accepter of Repentance

grammar.reason: One of Allah's names. The fa''āl pattern (with doubled middle letter) shows intensity - He accepts repentance ABUNDANTLY.
grammar.practical: 'At-Tawwāb' = 'The Oft-Returning' or 'The Ever-Accepter of Repentance'. One of the 99 names of Allah. The fa''āl pattern (تَوَّاب with double 'w') shows intensity and repetition - He doesn't just accept repentance once, but REPEATEDLY, CONSTANTLY! No matter how many times you turn to Him, He keeps accepting. The doubling shows abundance of this quality. From the same root t-w-b (to return/repent).

grammar.reason: Another of Allah's names. The fa'īl pattern shows continuous, lasting mercy.
grammar.practical: 'Ar-Raḥīm' = 'The Merciful' or 'Ever-Merciful'. One of the most frequently mentioned names of Allah. From 'raḥma' (mercy). The fa'īl pattern (رَحِيم) indicates permanent, continuous quality - He is ALWAYS merciful. Beautiful ending: even after such severe punishment was required, Allah's mercy prevailed. He accepted their repentance because He is at-Tawwāb ar-Raḥīm!

verses.arabic: وَإِذْ قُلْتُمْ يَٰمُوسَىٰ لَن نُّؤْمِنَ لَكَ حَتَّىٰ نَرَى ٱللَّهَ جَهْرَةً فَأَخَذَتْكُمُ ٱلصَّٰعِقَةُ وَأَنتُمْ تَنظُرُونَ
verses.transliteration: Wa idh qultum yā Mūsā lan nu'mina laka ḥattā nara Allāha jahratan fa'akhadhat kumu aṣ-ṣā'iqatu wa antum tanẓurūn
verses.translation: And when you said, 'O Moses, we will never believe you until we see Allah outright,' so the thunderbolt struck you while you were looking on

grammar.practical: 'And' - continuing the narrative of their rebellious acts
'When' - recalling another incident from their history

grammar.reason: Direct address - what THEY said. The 'tum' ending points to them as the speakers.
grammar.practical: From 'qāla' (to say). 'Qultum' = 'you (plural) said'. The 'tum' ending means 'you all did it'. Now we hear their words, their outrageous demand!

grammar.type: Harf + Ism - Vocative Particle + Proper Noun
grammar.practical: 'Yā' = 'O!'. 'Mūsā' = 'Moses'. Together: 'Yā Mūsā' = 'O Moses!' They're calling out to him, about to make their demand.

grammar.reason: Specifically negates the future. Stronger than 'lā' - means 'will NEVER' rather than just 'will not'.
grammar.practical: 'Lan' = 'will not' or 'never'. Used to negate future actions with emphasis. Stronger than simple 'lā'. They're saying: we will NEVER believe - categorical rejection! This is emphatic future negation.

grammar.root: أ-م-ن (a-m-n) - to believe, to have faith
grammar.reason: The verb after 'lan' must be in subjunctive mood. The 'nu' at start shows first person plural - 'we'. They're speaking about themselves.
grammar.practical: From ''āmana' (to believe - Form IV). 'Nu'minu' would be normal form, but after 'lan' it becomes 'nu'mina' (subjunctive). 'Nu'mina' = 'we believe'. The 'nu' at the beginning means 'we'. So 'lan nu'mina' = 'we will never believe'. Notice the doubled nūn (نُّ) - a writing feature in the Quran.

grammar.reason: Shows WHO they won't believe - you (Moses).
grammar.practical: 'Li' = 'for/to'. 'Ka' = 'you' (singular). Together: 'laka' = 'you' or 'for you'. 'We will never believe YOU' - rejecting Moses personally!

grammar.reason: Shows the CONDITION for their belief - until this happens.
grammar.practical: 'Ḥattā' = 'until'. Sets up their condition: we won't believe UNTIL... Shows what must happen before they'll believe. Sets a limit.

grammar.reason: After 'ḥattā', the verb is subjunctive. Shows their condition - until we SEE.
grammar.practical: From 'ra'ā' (to see). 'Nara' = 'we see'. The 'na' at the beginning (in 'nara') indicates first person plural = 'we'. Their outrageous condition: until we SEE Allah! This shows their spiritual blindness - demanding to see with physical eyes what can only be perceived with the heart.

grammar.reason: Direct object - WHAT they want to see. The fatha ending shows accusative case.
grammar.practical: 'Allāh' = Allah. The Name of God. With fatha ending (Allāha) shows it's the object of 'see'. They demand to see ALLAH Himself - an impossible, inappropriate demand showing their arrogance and lack of understanding. No one can see Allah in this world!

grammar.type: Ism - Verbal Noun (Maṣdar) used as Adverb (Ḥāl)
grammar.root: ج-ه-ر (j-h-r) - to be loud, open, manifest
grammar.reason: Describes HOW they want to see - openly, outright, manifestly. The tanwīn 'an' ending makes it an adverb.
grammar.practical: 'Jahrah' means 'openly/outright/manifestly/publicly'. From 'jahara' (to be open, loud, manifest). The 'an' ending makes it an adverb describing manner. They don't just want to see - they want to see OPENLY, CLEARLY, OUTRIGHT! Making their arrogant demand even worse. They want undeniable physical vision of Allah - showing complete misunderstanding of His transcendence.

words.translation: So struck you / So seized you

grammar.type: Harf + Fi'l - Conjunction + Past Tense Verb + Pronoun
grammar.root: أ-خ-ذ (a-kh-dh) - to take, to seize, to strike
grammar.person: Third person feminine singular + object pronoun
grammar.reason: Shows the CONSEQUENCE of their demand. The 'fa' indicates result. The 't' at end shows feminine subject (the thunderbolt). 'Kum' shows who it struck.
grammar.practical: 'Fa' = 'so/then' (showing consequence). 'Akhadha' = 'to take/seize' - but with violence, it means 'to strike/destroy'. 'Akhadhat' has the 't' at end showing feminine subject. 'Kum' = 'you (plural)'. Together: 'fa'akhadhat kumu' = 'so it struck you' or 'so it seized you'. The result of their arrogance - divine punishment struck them! The 'fa' shows immediate consequence.

grammar.root: ص-ع-ق (ṣ-'-q) - to strike with lightning, to stun
grammar.reason: Subject of the verb 'struck'. The 'u' ending shows nominative case. This is WHAT struck them.
grammar.practical: 'Aṣ-ṣā'iqah' = 'the thunderbolt' or 'the lightning strike'. From 'ṣa'aqa' (to strike with lightning, to stun, to shock). The pattern 'fā'ilah' (ṣā'iqah) shows the active thing doing the action. The 'u' ending shows it's the subject. This was a lightning strike from heaven as punishment for their outrageous demand! The definite article 'al' became 'aṣ' before ṣ (a sun letter).
'Wa' here means 'while' - describing their state when it happened. They were struck WHILE in this condition...
'Antum' = 'you (plural)'. Emphasizes the subject for the circumstantial clause.

words.translation: You are looking / You are watching

grammar.root: ن-ظ-ر (n-ẓ-r) - to look, to see, to watch
grammar.reason: Describes their state WHILE being struck - they were watching. The 'ta' prefix with 'ūna' ending = 'you (plural) are doing'.
grammar.practical: From 'naẓara' (to look/see/watch). 'Tanẓurūna' = 'you (plural) are looking/watching'. The 'ta...ūna' pattern means 'you (plural) do'. Chilling detail: they were struck by the thunderbolt WHILE THEY WERE LOOKING - they saw it coming! They demanded to see Allah, and instead they saw His punishment! The irony is profound.

verses.arabic: ثُمَّ بَعَثْنَٰكُم مِّنۢ بَعْدِ مَوْتِكُمْ لَعَلَّكُمْ تَشْكُرُونَ
verses.transliteration: Thumma ba'athnākum min ba'di mawtikum la'allakum tashkurūn
verses.translation: Then We revived you after your death so that you might be grateful

grammar.practical: 'Thumma' = 'then' (with delay). After they were struck dead by the thunderbolt, THEN came Allah's mercy.

words.translation: We resurrected you / We raised you up

grammar.root: ب-ع-ث (b-'-th) - to send, to raise, to resurrect
grammar.reason: Shows Allah's action of bringing them back to life. The 'nā' shows the doer (We = Allah), 'kum' shows who was resurrected (you).
grammar.practical: From 'ba'atha' (to send/raise/resurrect). 'Ba'athnā' = 'We raised/resurrected'. 'Kum' = 'you'. Together: 'ba'athnākum' = 'We resurrected you'. This root b-'-th is used for sending forth and for resurrection on the Day of Judgment. Here it means Allah brought them back to life after the thunderbolt killed them! Amazing mercy - they died for their arrogance, then Allah gave them another chance!
'Min' = 'from', indicating the starting point in time - from after their death.
'Ba'd' = 'after'. With 'min': 'from after' = after. The 'i' ending shows genitive case.

grammar.reason: Shows WHEN they were raised - after YOUR death. The possessive 'kum' makes it personal.
grammar.practical: 'Mawt' = 'death' (verbal noun from 'māta' - to die). 'Kum' = 'your'. Together: 'mawtikum' = 'your death'. The 'i' ending shows it's in a possessive construct. 'Min ba'di mawtikum' = 'from after your death' = 'after you died'. They actually DIED from the thunderbolt, then Allah brought them back!

words.translation: So that you may / Perhaps you

grammar.type: Harf + Ism - Particle of Hope + Pronoun
grammar.practical: 'La'allakum' = 'so that you may' or 'perhaps you'. Shows the PURPOSE of giving them another chance - hoping they'd be grateful!

words.translation: You are grateful / You give thanks

grammar.practical: 'Tashkurūna' = 'you are grateful'. From 'shakara' (to be grateful). Allah brought them back from death SO THAT they would be grateful - another chance at life, another chance to be thankful!

verses.arabic: وَظَلَّلْنَا عَلَيْكُمُ ٱلْغَمَامَ وَأَنزَلْنَا عَلَيْكُمُ ٱلْمَنَّ وَٱلسَّلْوَىٰ ۖ كُلُوا۟ مِن طَيِّبَٰتِ مَا رَزَقْنَٰكُمْ ۖ وَمَا ظَلَمُونَا وَلَٰكِن كَانُوا۟ أَنفُسَهُمْ يَظْلِمُونَ
verses.transliteration: Wa ẓallalnā 'alaykumu al-ghamāma wa anzalnā 'alaykumu al-manna was-salwā kulū min ṭayyibāti mā razaqnākum wa mā ẓalamūnā wa lākin kānū anfusahum yaẓlimūn
verses.translation: And We shaded you with clouds and sent down to you manna and quails, [saying], 'Eat from the good things We have provided for you.' And they did not wrong Us, but they were [only] wronging themselves

grammar.practical: 'And' - continuing the list of Allah's favors

grammar.reason: Form II with doubled middle letter shows intensive or causative action. Made to have shade. The 'nā' shows Allah is the doer.
grammar.practical: From 'ẓill' (shade/shadow). In Form II: 'ẓallala' means to provide shade or make shade over something. 'Ẓallalnā' = 'We shaded' or 'We provided shade'. The doubled lām (ظَلَّلْ) is characteristic of Form II. Allah provided them shade in the desert - a tremendous blessing!
''Alā' = 'over/upon'. 'Kum' = 'you'. Together: ''alaykumu' = 'over you'. The shade was OVER them, protecting them.

grammar.reason: Direct object - WHAT provided the shade. The 'a' ending shows accusative.
grammar.practical: 'Al-ghamām' = 'the clouds'. From 'ghamm' (clouds, mist, overcast). These were special clouds Allah sent to protect them from the desert heat during their wandering. The 'a' ending shows this is the object - WHAT Allah shaded them with.
'And' - adding another blessing

grammar.root: ن-ز-ل (n-z-l) - to descend, to send down
grammar.reason: Form IV means to cause to descend - to send down. The 'nā' indicates Allah as the sender.
grammar.practical: From 'nazala' (to descend). In Form IV: 'anzala' means to send down, to cause to descend. 'Anzalnā' = 'We sent down'. This is the verb used for sending down revelation (Quran) and also for sending down provisions! The 'nā' = 'We' (Allah).
''Alaykumu' = 'upon you' or 'to you'. The food was sent down TO them.

grammar.reason: Direct object of 'sent down' - what was sent. First type of food mentioned.
grammar.practical: 'Al-mann' = 'the manna'. A sweet substance (like honey or gum) that miraculously appeared for them to eat in the wilderness. From the root 'manna' (to bestow favor) - it was a pure favor from Allah! The 'a' ending shows it's the object of the verb.
'And' - connecting the two types of food

grammar.reason: Second direct object - the other food sent down. Ends in alif maqṣūrah.
grammar.practical: 'As-salwā' = 'the quails'. A type of bird that was sent to them as meat. Some say it was quails, others say a type of bird. Another miraculous provision in the desert! Ends in alif maqṣūrah (ٰى) so doesn't show case ending.

grammar.reason: Command to eat - Allah's permission and encouragement. The 'ū' ending indicates plural command.
grammar.practical: From 'akala' (to eat). 'Kulū' = 'Eat!' (command to group). Allah is telling them: EAT from what I've given you! The small circle (۟) is a Quranic marking. What a blessing - free food falling from the sky, and Allah saying 'Eat!'
'Min' = 'from' or 'of'. Indicates eating FROM/some of the good things. Partitive meaning.

words.translation: The good things / The pure things

grammar.root: ط-ي-ب (ṭ-y-b) - to be good, pure, wholesome
grammar.reason: Describes the provisions as good and pure. The 'i' ending shows genitive case after preposition 'min'.
grammar.practical: 'Ṭayyib' means good, pure, wholesome, lawful. 'Ṭayyibāt' is the feminine plural = 'good things' or 'pure things'. The 'i' ending (ṭayyibāti) shows genitive case. These provisions weren't just food - they were GOOD, PURE food from Allah!
'Mā' = 'what' or 'that which'. Introduces what follows: 'the good things of WHAT We provided you' = 'the good things We provided you'.

grammar.reason: Complete verb with subject and object. Shows Allah as provider, them as recipients.
grammar.practical: 'Razaqa' = 'provided'. 'Nā' = 'We'. 'Kum' = 'you'. Together: 'razaqnākum' = 'We provided you'. From r-z-q (provision/sustenance). Beautiful reminder: everything they eat is from Allah's provision!
'And' - transitioning to their response
'Mā' = 'not'. Negates what follows: they did NOT...

grammar.reason: Shift to third person - talking ABOUT them now, not TO them. Shows their ingratitude couldn't harm Allah.
grammar.practical: From 'ẓalama' (to wrong). 'Ẓalamū' = 'they wronged'. 'Nā' = 'Us' (Allah). Together: 'ẓalamūnā' = 'they wronged Us'. The 'ū' shows plural subject. But negated: 'mā ẓalamūnā' = 'they did NOT wrong Us'. When people disobey, they can't actually HARM Allah - He's beyond being affected!

grammar.reason: Contrasts who was actually harmed. Not Allah, BUT...
grammar.practical: 'Wa' = 'and'. 'Lākin' = 'but/however'. Together: 'wa lākin' = 'but' or 'however'. Shows contrast: They didn't wrong Us, BUT (they did wrong someone)...

grammar.type: Fi'l - Past Tense Verb (Defective Verb - Kāna)
grammar.function: Expresses state of being in past
grammar.reason: Kāna is a special verb that describes states/conditions. The 'ū' shows plural subject.
grammar.practical: 'Kāna' = 'to be' or 'was'. 'Kānū' = 'they were'. One of the most important verbs in Arabic - describes states and conditions. 'Kānū' with plural subject means 'they were (in a state of)...'.

grammar.reason: Object of the verb 'wronging' that follows. They were wronging THEMSELVES. The 'a' ending shows accusative.
grammar.practical: 'Anfus' = 'selves' (plural). 'Hum' = 'their'. Together: 'anfusahum' = 'themselves/their own selves'. Emphasis: when they sinned, they harmed THEMSELVES, not Allah!

grammar.reason: Predicate of kāna. Shows continuous action: they WERE (continuously) wronging themselves.
grammar.practical: From 'ẓalama' (to wrong). 'Yaẓlimūna' = 'they wrong/are wronging'. The 'ya...ūna' pattern = 'they do'. With kāna: 'kānū yaẓlimūna' = 'they were wronging' (continuous past action). Beautiful construction showing they were CONTINUOUSLY wronging themselves through their ingratitude!

verses.arabic: وَإِذْ قُلْنَا ٱدْخُلُوا۟ هَٰذِهِ ٱلْقَرْيَةَ فَكُلُوا۟ مِنْهَا حَيْثُ شِئْتُمْ رَغَدًا وَٱدْخُلُوا۟ ٱلْبَابَ سُجَّدًا وَقُولُوا۟ حِطَّةٌ نَّغْفِرْ لَكُمْ خَطَٰيَٰكُمْ ۚ وَسَنَزِيدُ ٱلْمُحْسِنِينَ
verses.transliteration: Wa idh qulnā udkhulū hādhihi al-qaryata fakulū minhā ḥaythu shi'tum raghadan wadkhulū al-bāba sujjadan wa qūlū ḥiṭṭatun naghfir lakum khaṭāyākum wa sanazīdu al-muḥsinīn
verses.translation: And when We said, 'Enter this city and eat from it wherever you will in [ease and] abundance, and enter the gate bowing humbly, and say, 'Relieve us of our burdens.' We will [then] forgive your sins and increase the doers of good'

grammar.practical: 'And' - another historical event
'When' - recalling another moment
'Qāla' = 'to say'. 'Qulnā' = 'We said'. Allah said to them...
From 'dakhala' (to enter). 'Udkhulū' = 'Enter!' (command to group). Allah's command to enter the city.
'Hādhihi' = 'this' (feminine form). Points to the city (qaryah - feminine word). THIS city specifically.

grammar.reason: Direct object of 'enter'. What they should enter. The 'a' ending shows accusative.
grammar.practical: 'Al-qaryah' = 'the city' or 'the town'. Refers to Jerusalem or another city they were commanded to enter. The 'a' ending (al-qaryata) shows accusative case.
'Fa' = 'so/then'. 'Kulū' = 'eat!' Together: 'so eat' or 'then eat'. After entering, EAT from it!
'Min' = 'from'. 'Hā' = 'it' (the city). Together: 'minhā' = 'from it'. Eat FROM the city's provisions.
'Ḥaythu' = 'where' or 'wherever'. Gives them freedom: eat from WHEREVER you wish in the city!

grammar.root: ش-ي-أ (sh-y-') - to will, to wish, to want
grammar.practical: From 'shā'a' (to will/wish/want). 'Shi'tum' = 'you wished/willed'. With 'ḥaythu': 'wherever you wish'. Complete freedom to eat wherever they wanted!

grammar.reason: Describes the STATE or manner of eating - eat in ABUNDANCE. The 'an' ending makes it adverbial.
grammar.practical: 'Raghad' means abundance, plenty, comfort, ease. The 'an' ending (raghadan) makes it describe the manner: eat ABUNDANTLY, COMFORTABLY, in PLENTY! Not just eat - eat well, with ease and comfort!
'Wa' = 'and'. 'Udkhulū' = 'enter!' Another command: And ENTER (the gate)...
'Al-bāb' = 'the gate' or 'the door'. The 'a' ending shows accusative - enter THE GATE.

grammar.reason: Describes their STATE when entering - enter WHILE bowing/prostrating. The 'an' ending makes it adverbial.
grammar.practical: 'Sajada' = 'to prostrate/bow'. 'Sujjadan' is plural active participle with tanwīn = 'prostrating ones' or 'in prostration/bowing'. Describes how to enter: in HUMILITY, BOWING, showing submission to Allah. Not arrogantly, but humbly!
'Wa' = 'and'. 'Qūlū' = 'say!' Third command: And SAY...

grammar.root: ح-ط-ط (ḥ-ṭ-ṭ) - to put down, to relieve, to remove
grammar.reason: The word they were commanded to say. Means 'put down (our burdens)' or 'relieve us' or 'forgiveness'. The 'un' ending gives it emphasis.
grammar.practical: 'Ḥiṭṭah' is a verbal noun from 'ḥaṭṭa' (to put down, remove burdens). Means 'a putting down' or 'a relieving' - asking Allah to PUT DOWN/REMOVE their sins and burdens. Like saying 'Forgive us' or 'Relieve us of our burdens'. The tanwīn 'un' adds emphasis. Simple word carrying deep meaning of seeking forgiveness!

grammar.root: غ-ف-ر (gh-f-r) - to forgive, to cover sins
grammar.reason: Allah's response to their obedience. The 'na' shows first person = We (Allah). Jussive form gives it future/conditional meaning.
grammar.practical: From 'ghafara' (to forgive/cover sins). 'Naghfiru' would be normal, but jussive makes it 'naghfir' = 'We will forgive' or 'We shall forgive'. The 'na' = 'We' (Allah). Allah's promise: If you do this (enter humbly and say hiṭṭah), We WILL forgive! The doubled nūn (نَّ) is a writing feature.
'Li' = 'for'. 'Kum' = 'you'. Together: 'lakum' = 'for you'. We will forgive FOR you = We will forgive you.

grammar.root: خ-ط-أ (kh-ṭ-') - to err, to sin, to miss the mark
grammar.practical: 'Khaṭī'ah' = 'sin/error/mistake'. 'Khaṭāyā' is the plural = 'sins/errors'. From 'khaṭi'a' (to err, sin, miss the mark). 'Kum' = 'your'. Together: 'khaṭāyākum' = 'your sins'. WHAT will be forgiven - your sins/mistakes/errors!
'And' - adding more good news

words.translation: We will increase / We shall increase

grammar.reason: The 'sa' at beginning makes it future tense. Allah's additional promise.
grammar.practical: From 'zāda' (to increase/add). 'Nazīdu' = 'We increase'. With 'sa': 'sanazīdu' = 'We WILL increase' or 'We shall increase'. The 'sa' prefix makes verbs future tense. Not only forgiveness, but INCREASE in goodness too!

words.translation: The good-doers / Those who do good

grammar.reason: WHO Allah will increase - the good-doers. Form IV means 'those who do iḥsān (excellence)'.
grammar.practical: 'Aḥsana' (Form IV of ḥasuna) means to do good, to do excellently, to beautify. 'Muḥsin' = 'one who does iḥsān (excellence/good)'. 'Muḥsinīn' is plural = 'those who do good/the excellent ones'. The 'īna' ending shows accusative plural. Beautiful promise: We will INCREASE the good-doers - in blessings, rewards, good deeds, everything!

verses.arabic: فَبَدَّلَ ٱلَّذِينَ ظَلَمُوا۟ قَوْلًا غَيْرَ ٱلَّذِى قِيلَ لَهُمْ فَأَنزَلْنَا عَلَى ٱلَّذِينَ ظَلَمُوا۟ رِجْزًا مِّنَ ٱلسَّمَآءِ بِمَا كَانُوا۟ يَفْسُقُونَ
verses.transliteration: Fabaddala alladhīna ẓalamū qawlan ghayra alladhī qīla lahum fa'anzalnā 'alā alladhīna ẓalamū rijzan mina as-samā'i bimā kānū yafsuqūn
verses.translation: But those who wronged changed [that] to a statement other than that which had been said to them, so We sent down upon those who wronged a punishment from the sky because they were defiantly disobedient

grammar.type: Harf + Fi'l - Conjunction + Past Tense Verb
grammar.root: ب-د-ل (b-d-l) - to change, to substitute, to replace
grammar.reason: The 'fa' shows consequence - they were told to do something, SO what did they do? Form II (doubled dāl) shows intensive changing.
grammar.practical: 'Fa' = 'so/then' (consequence). From 'badala' (to change/replace). Form II 'baddala' means to change completely or substitute. 'Baddala' = 'he/it changed'. But who changed? The subject comes next. This shows their disobedience - instead of obeying, they CHANGED what they were told!

grammar.function: Subject of the verb - who changed
grammar.practical: 'Alladhīna' = 'those who'. Subject: THOSE WHO wronged did the changing. Starts describing the wrongdoers.
From 'ẓalama' (to wrong). 'Ẓalamū' = 'they wronged'. Describes WHO they are: 'those who wronged' or 'the wrongdoers'. They wronged themselves by disobeying.

words.translation: A word / A statement / A saying

grammar.reason: Direct object of 'changed'. WHAT did they change? A word/statement.
grammar.practical: 'Qawl' is the verbal noun of 'qāla' (to say) = 'a saying/word/statement'. The 'an' ending (qawlan) shows accusative. They changed A WORD - they were supposed to say 'ḥiṭṭah' but they changed it!

grammar.function: Describes the word - OTHER than what was commanded
grammar.practical: 'Ghayr' means 'other than' or 'different from'. 'Ghayra' with fatha shows it describes 'qawlan': 'a word OTHER THAN...' They said something DIFFERENT from what they were told!
'Alladhī' = 'that which' or 'what'. Introduces what follows: 'other than WHAT was said to them'.

grammar.reason: Passive voice - 'it was said' (by Allah). The doer (Allah) is implied but not stated.
grammar.practical: From 'qāla' (to say). In passive: 'qīla' = 'it was said' or 'was said'. The 'ī' vowel is characteristic of passive voice in Arabic. Passive means we focus on WHAT was said, not who said it (though we know it's Allah's command).
'Li' = 'to/for'. 'Hum' = 'them'. Together: 'lahum' = 'to them'. It was said TO them - they were the ones addressed with the command.

grammar.type: Harf + Fi'l - Conjunction + Past Tense Verb
grammar.reason: The 'fa' shows immediate consequence of their disobedience. They changed the word, SO Allah sent down punishment.
grammar.practical: 'Fa' = 'so' (immediate consequence). 'Anzala' = 'to send down' (Form IV). 'Nā' = 'We' (Allah). Together: 'fa'anzalnā' = 'so We sent down'. Their mockery brought immediate punishment from above!

grammar.function: Indicates who received the punishment - upon
grammar.practical: ''Alā' = 'upon/on'. The punishment came down UPON them.
'Alladhīna' = 'those who'. WHO received the punishment? Those who...
'Ẓalamū' = 'they wronged'. Repeated phrase: 'those who wronged' - the wrongdoers. Emphasizes their wrongdoing.

grammar.reason: Direct object of 'sent down'. WHAT was sent down? Punishment/plague.
grammar.practical: 'Rijz' means punishment, plague, or filth/abomination. Something disgusting and punishing. The 'an' ending (rijzan) shows accusative. WHAT Allah sent down: a terrible punishment! Could be plague, disease, or other calamity.
'Min' = 'from'. Shows WHERE the punishment came from...

grammar.reason: Shows SOURCE of punishment. The 'i' ending shows genitive after preposition.
grammar.practical: 'As-samā'' = 'the heaven/sky'. The 'i' ending (as-samā'i) shows genitive. 'Min as-samā'i' = 'from the heaven/sky'. The punishment came from ABOVE - from the sky/heaven. Could not escape it!
'Bi' = 'by/with/because'. 'Mā' = 'what'. Together: 'bimā' = 'because of what' or 'due to what'. Shows the REASON for the punishment.
'Kāna' = 'to be'. 'Kānū' = 'they were'. Describes their continuous state.

words.translation: They disobey / They transgress / They rebel

grammar.root: ف-س-ق (f-s-q) - to transgress, to disobey, to deviate
grammar.reason: With kānū, shows continuous action in the past: they WERE (continuously) transgressing.
grammar.practical: From 'fasaqa' (to transgress/disobey/deviate from the right path). 'Yafsuqūna' = 'they transgress/disobey'. With 'kānū': 'kānū yafsuqūna' = 'they were (continuously) transgressing'. Fisq is deliberate, defiant disobedience. Not just a mistake - rebellious transgression! This was their state: constant, defiant disobedience. That's why punishment came.

verses.arabic: وَإِذِ ٱسْتَسْقَىٰ مُوسَىٰ لِقَوْمِهِۦ فَقُلْنَا ٱضْرِب بِّعَصَاكَ ٱلْحَجَرَ ۖ فَٱنفَجَرَتْ مِنْهُ ٱثْنَتَا عَشْرَةَ عَيْنًا ۖ قَدْ عَلِمَ كُلُّ أُنَاسٍ مَّشْرَبَهُمْ ۖ كُلُوا۟ وَٱشْرَبُوا۟ مِن رِّزْقِ ٱللَّهِ وَلَا تَعْثَوْا۟ فِى ٱلْأَرْضِ مُفْسِدِينَ
verses.transliteration: Wa idhi istasqā Mūsā liqawmihi faqulnā iḍrib bi'aṣāka al-ḥajara fanfajarat minhu ithnatā 'ashrata 'aynan qad 'alima kullu unāsin mashrabahum kulū washrabū min rizqi Allāhi wa lā ta'thaw fī al-arḍi mufsidīn
verses.translation: And when Moses asked for water for his people, We said, 'Strike with your staff the stone.' Then gushed forth from it twelve springs, and every tribe knew its drinking place. [We said], 'Eat and drink from the provision of Allah, and do not commit abuse on the earth, spreading corruption'

grammar.practical: 'And' - another blessing being recalled
'Idh' = 'when'. Another historical moment.

words.translation: He asked for water / He sought water

grammar.root: س-ق-ي (s-q-y) - to give water, to drink
grammar.reason: Form X means to seek or ask for something. Istasqā = to ask for water/rain. The pattern shows seeking.
grammar.practical: From 'saqā' (to give water/drink). Form X 'istasqā' means to ask for water, to seek water/rain. 'Istasqā' = 'he asked for water'. The 'ista-' prefix is characteristic of Form X (seeking/requesting). Moses ASKED FOR water on behalf of his people.
Moses - the subject. HE is the one who asked for water.
'Liqawmihi' = 'for his people'. Moses asked FOR HIS PEOPLE - showing his care for them despite their rebellion.

grammar.type: Harf + Fi'l - Conjunction + Past Tense Verb
grammar.practical: 'Fa' = 'so' (consequence). 'Qulnā' = 'We said'. He asked, SO We responded...
From 'ḍaraba' (to strike/hit). 'Iḍrib' = 'Strike!' (command to Moses). Allah's solution: STRIKE (the rock)!

grammar.reason: The INSTRUMENT of striking. The 'bi' shows what to use.
grammar.practical: 'Bi' = 'with/by' (shows instrument). ''Aṣā' = 'staff/stick'. 'Ka' = 'your'. Together: 'bi'aṣāka' = 'with your staff'. Strike WITH YOUR STAFF - the same staff that turned into a serpent before Pharaoh!
'Al-ḥajar' = 'the stone/rock'. The 'a' ending shows accusative - WHAT to strike. Strike THE ROCK!

words.translation: So gushed forth / So burst forth

grammar.type: Harf + Fi'l - Conjunction + Past Tense Verb
grammar.root: ف-ج-ر (f-j-r) - to split open, to gush
grammar.reason: Form VII shows reflexive/passive action - it gushed BY ITSELF. The 't' shows feminine subject (water springs). 'Fa' shows immediate result.
grammar.practical: 'Fa' = 'so' (immediate result). From 'fajara' (to split/burst). Form VII 'infajara' = to burst open, to gush forth BY ITSELF. 'Infajarat' has 't' at end showing feminine subject. Together: 'fanfajarat' = 'so it burst forth' or 'so they gushed forth'. He struck, and IMMEDIATELY water gushed out!
'Min' = 'from'. 'Hu' = 'it' (the rock). Together: 'minhu' = 'from it'. Water gushed FROM IT - from the rock!

grammar.reason: First part of compound number 'twelve'. With feminine form because it counts feminine noun ('springs').
grammar.practical: 'Ithnān' = 'two' (masculine). 'Ithnatān' = 'two' (feminine). Here: 'ithnatā' is the nominative feminine form. Part of the number 'twelve' (ithnatā 'ashrata). In Arabic 11-19, the number has two parts that must agree!

grammar.reason: Second part of compound number. Together with ithnatā = twelve.
grammar.practical: ''Asharah' = 'ten'. In compound numbers 11-19, 'ten' part is in accusative. ''Ashrata' is the feminine form used here. Together: 'ithnatā 'ashrata' = 'twelve' (literally 'two-ten'). Strange but beautiful: in Arabic, you say 'two-ten' instead of 'twelve'!

grammar.reason: Specifies WHAT there are twelve of. Tamyīz (specification) after numbers. Singular even though meaning plural.
grammar.practical: ''Ayn' means 'eye' or 'spring/fountain' (water source). The 'an' ending ('aynan) shows accusative - tamyīz after numbers. Twelve SPRINGS! Even though it's twelve, Arabic uses SINGULAR form after numbers. One rock produced TWELVE springs - one for each tribe!
'Qad' is a particle that emphasizes or shows completion. With past verbs: 'certainly/already'. Makes the statement definite.
From ''alima' (to know). ''Alima' = 'he knew' or 'it knew'. With 'qad': 'qad 'alima' = 'indeed knew' or 'certainly knew'.
'Kull' = 'all/every/each'. 'Kullu' with dammah is nominative - the subject. 'Each' or 'every' group...

grammar.reason: In possessive construct with 'kull'. The 'in' ending shows genitive with tanwīn.
grammar.practical: ''Unās' = 'people/group'. From root a-n-s (related to humans/people). The 'in' ending shows genitive - in construct with 'kull'. 'Kullu unāsin' = 'every group of people' or 'each tribe'. Each tribe knew their spot!

grammar.type: Ism - Noun (Place Noun - Ism Makān) + Pronoun
grammar.reason: Place noun pattern (ma-) shows WHERE the action happens. The possessive 'hum' makes it 'their place'.
grammar.practical: From 'shariba' (to drink). 'Mashrab' is the place noun (ma- prefix) = 'drinking place'. 'Hum' = 'their'. Together: 'mashrabahum' = 'their drinking place'. Each tribe knew WHICH spring was theirs! The 'a' ending shows it's the object of 'knew'. Perfect organization - twelve tribes, twelve springs!
'Kulū' = 'Eat!' Command from Allah - permission and command to eat from His provisions.
'Wa' = 'and'. 'Ishrabū' = 'Drink!' Together: 'And drink!' Allah's provision includes both food and water!
'Min' = 'from'. Eat and drink FROM...

words.translation: The provision of / The sustenance of

grammar.practical: 'Rizq' = 'provision/sustenance'. The 'i' ending shows genitive (after min and in construct). 'Rizqi' = 'the provision of...'
'Allāh' with kasra (Allāhi) shows genitive. 'Rizqi Allāhi' = 'the provision of Allah'. Everything comes from Allah!
'Wa' = 'and'. 'Lā' = 'not'. Together with command verb = prohibition: 'And do NOT...'

words.translation: You commit abuse / You act corruptly / You spread mischief

grammar.root: ع-ث-و ('-th-w) - to commit abuse, to act corruptly
grammar.practical: From ''athā' (to commit abuse/corruption/mischief). 'Ta'thaw' is jussive form (prohibition) = 'do not commit abuse'. Rare verb meaning to spread corruption and mischief on earth.
'Fī' = 'in/on'. WHERE not to spread corruption - in/on the earth.
'Al-arḍ' = 'the earth/land'. The 'i' ending shows genitive. 'Fī al-arḍi' = 'on the earth'. Don't spread corruption ON THE EARTH!

grammar.reason: Describes their STATE while committing abuse - AS corrupters. Form IV means causing corruption.
grammar.practical: From 'fasada' (to be corrupt). Form IV 'afsada' = to cause corruption, to spoil. 'Mufsid' = 'one who causes corruption/corrupter'. 'Mufsidīna' is plural accusative = 'as corrupters/corrupting ones'. The 'īna' ending shows accusative ḥāl. Don't act corruptly on earth AS SPREADERS OF CORRUPTION! Warning against causing fasād (corruption/mischief) after receiving such blessings!

verses.arabic: وَإِذْ قُلْتُمْ يَٰمُوسَىٰ لَن نَّصْبِرَ عَلَىٰ طَعَامٍ وَٰحِدٍ فَٱدْعُ لَنَا رَبَّكَ يُخْرِجْ لَنَا مِمَّا تُنۢبِتُ ٱلْأَرْضُ مِنۢ بَقْلِهَا وَقِثَّآئِهَا وَفُومِهَا وَعَدَسِهَا وَبَصَلِهَا ۖ قَالَ أَتَسْتَبْدِلُونَ ٱلَّذِى هُوَ أَدْنَىٰ بِٱلَّذِى هُوَ خَيْرٌ ۚ ٱهْبِطُوا۟ مِصْرًا فَإِنَّ لَكُم مَّا سَأَلْتُمْ ۗ وَضُرِبَتْ عَلَيْهِمُ ٱلذِّلَّةُ وَٱلْمَسْكَنَةُ وَبَآءُو بِغَضَبٍ مِّنَ ٱللَّهِ ۗ ذَٰلِكَ بِأَنَّهُمْ كَانُوا۟ يَكْفُرُونَ بِـَٔايَٰتِ ٱللَّهِ وَيَقْتُلُونَ ٱلنَّبِيِّۦنَ بِغَيْرِ ٱلْحَقِّ ۗ ذَٰلِكَ بِمَا عَصَوا۟ وَّكَانُوا۟ يَعْتَدُونَ
verses.transliteration: Wa idh qultum yā Mūsā lan naṣbira 'alā ṭa'āmin wāḥidin fad'u lanā rabbaka yukhrij lanā mimmā tunbitu al-arḍu min baqlihā wa qiththā'ihā wa fūmihā wa 'adasihā wa baṣalihā qāla atastabdilūna alladhī huwa adnā billadhī huwa khayrun ihbiṭū miṣran fa'inna lakum mā sa'altum wa ḍuribat 'alayhimu adh-dhillatu wal-maskanatu wa bā'ū bighaḍabin mina Allāhi dhālika bi'annahum kānū yakfurūna bi'āyāti Allāhi wa yaqtulūna an-nabiyyīna bighayri al-ḥaqqi dhālika bimā 'aṣaw wa kānū ya'tadūn
verses.translation: And [recall] when you said, 'O Moses, we can never endure one [kind of] food. So call upon your Lord to bring forth for us from the earth its green herbs and its cucumbers and its garlic and its lentils and its onions.' [Moses] said, 'Would you exchange what is better for what is less? Go into [any] settlement and indeed, you will have what you have asked.' And they were covered with humiliation and poverty and returned with anger from Allah. That was because they [repeatedly] disbelieved in the signs of Allah and killed the prophets without right. That was because they disobeyed and were [habitually] transgressing

grammar.practical: 'Wa idh' = 'And when/remember when'. Another incident from their history.
'Qultum' = 'you (plural) said'. Another complaint from them!
'Yā Mūsā' = 'O Moses!' Calling him again with another demand.
'Lan' = 'will never'. Emphatic future negation - we will NEVER endure!

grammar.root: ص-ب-ر (ṣ-b-r) - to be patient, to endure
grammar.practical: From 'ṣabara' (to be patient/endure). 'Naṣbira' (subjunctive) = 'we be patient/endure'. With 'lan': 'we will never be patient!'
''Alā' = 'upon/to'. Shows what they can't endure.

grammar.root: ط-ع-م (ṭ-'-m) - to eat, to taste, food
grammar.practical: 'Ṭa'ām' = 'food'. The 'in' ending shows genitive. Can't endure ONE KIND of food!
'Wāḥid' = 'one/single'. Describes the food - ONE kind! Ungrateful - complaining about miraculous food from heaven!
'Fa' = 'so'. 'Ud'u' = 'call/invoke!' (command). Together: 'So call!' They're ordering Moses to make du'a!
'Lanā' = 'for us'. Call FOR US - on our behalf.
'Rabb' = 'Lord'. 'Ka' = 'your'. Together: 'rabbaka' = 'your Lord'. Notice: they say YOUR Lord, not OUR Lord - distancing themselves!

grammar.root: خ-ر-ج (kh-r-j) - to go out, to bring out
grammar.practical: From 'kharaja' (to exit). Form IV 'akhraja' = to bring out/produce. 'Yukhrij' (jussive) = 'may He bring forth'. Shows purpose of the du'a.
'Lanā' = 'for us'. Bring forth FOR US.
'Mimmā' = 'from what'. FROM WHAT grows...
From 'nabata' (to sprout). Form IV 'anbata' = to cause to grow, to produce. 'Tunbitu' = 'it produces/grows'. Earth (feminine) is the subject.
'Al-arḍ' = 'the earth'. Subject - WHAT produces. The 'u' shows nominative case.
'Min' = 'of/from'. Specifies WHAT the earth produces - introduces the list.
'Baql' = 'herbs/vegetables/greens'. 'Hā' = 'its' (the earth's). 'Baqlihā' = 'its herbs'. First item on their shopping list!
'Qiththā'' = 'cucumbers'. 'Hā' = 'its'. Second item - cucumbers!
'Fūm' = 'garlic' (or possibly wheat). Third item on the list!
''Adas' = 'lentils'. Fourth item!
'Baṣal' = 'onions'. Fifth item! Demanding earthly vegetables instead of being grateful for heavenly food!
'Qāla' = 'he said'. Moses' response...

words.translation: Do you exchange? / Would you substitute?

grammar.reason: The 'a' at beginning makes it interrogative. Form X means to seek to exchange.
grammar.practical: From 'badala' (to change). Form X 'istabdala' = to seek to exchange, to substitute. 'Atastabdilūna' with interrogative 'a' = 'Do you exchange?' Moses is shocked at their request!
'Alladhī' = 'that which/what'. Introduces WHAT they're exchanging...
'Huwa' = 'it'. Emphasizes the subject.
'Adnā' = 'lower/lesser/inferior/nearer'. The earthly vegetables are LESSER in quality and value!
'Billadhī' = 'for that which/with what'. Exchange the lesser FOR what?
'Huwa' = 'it'. Emphasis again.
'Khayr' = 'better/superior'. The heavenly food (manna and quails) is BETTER! Exchanging better for worse - foolishness!

grammar.root: ه-ب-ط (h-b-ṭ) - to descend, to go down
grammar.practical: 'Ihbiṭū' = 'Go down/Descend!' Command to go down (from the wilderness) to settled areas. Like: 'Fine, go to any city!'
'Miṣr' can mean 'Egypt' or 'a city/settlement'. With tanwīn (miṣran) = 'a city' - any settled place. Go to ANY city!
'Fa'inna' = 'for indeed/then indeed'. Emphasizes what follows.
'Lakum' = 'for you'. Available FOR YOU...
'Mā' = 'what'. WHAT you asked for...
'Sa'altum' = 'you asked'. There - you'll find WHAT you asked for in any city!

words.translation: And was struck / And was set upon

grammar.type: Harf + Fi'l - Conjunction + Past Passive Verb
grammar.practical: 'Wa' = 'and'. 'Ḍuribat' (passive with feminine 't') = 'was struck/set upon'. Their punishment...
''Alayhimu' = 'upon them'. Was struck UPON THEM...

grammar.root: ذ-ل-ل (dh-l-l) - to be humiliated, to be lowly
grammar.practical: 'Adh-dhillah' = 'the humiliation/disgrace'. From 'dhalla' (to be humiliated). They were covered with HUMILIATION!

words.translation: And the poverty / And the wretchedness

grammar.practical: 'Wal-maskanah' = 'and the poverty/wretchedness'. From 'sakana'. They were struck with humiliation AND poverty!

words.translation: And they returned / And they earned

grammar.root: ب-و-أ (b-w-') - to return with, to deserve
grammar.practical: 'Wa' = 'and'. 'Bā'ū' = 'they returned with/earned/deserved'. They EARNED/RETURNED WITH anger...
'Bi' = 'with'. 'Ghaḍab' = 'anger/wrath'. They earned ANGER...
'Min' = 'from'. Anger FROM...
'Allāhi' (genitive) = Allah. Anger FROM ALLAH - the worst kind!
'Dhālika' = 'that'. Points to what just mentioned - THAT punishment...
'Bi'annahum' = 'because they' or 'because indeed they'. Shows the REASON for punishment.
'Kānū' = 'they were/used to'. Describes their continuous state.

grammar.root: ك-ف-ر (k-f-r) - to disbelieve, to reject, to cover truth
grammar.practical: From 'kafara' (to disbelieve/reject/cover). 'Yakfurūna' = 'they disbelieve'. With kānū: 'they WERE (habitually) disbelieving'.

words.translation: In the signs of / In the verses of

grammar.practical: 'Bi' = 'in/with'. 'Āyāt' = 'signs/verses/miracles' (plural of āyah). They disbelieved IN the signs...
Allah's signs - all the miracles and revelations!
'Wa yaqtulūna' = 'and they kill'. Adds their second major crime!

grammar.root: ن-ب-أ (n-b-') - prophet, one who brings news
grammar.practical: 'An-nabiyyīn' = 'the prophets' (plural of nabī). The 'īna' shows accusative plural. They KILLED THE PROPHETS!
'Bighayri' = 'without/with other than'. Killed WITHOUT...
'Al-ḥaqq' = 'the truth/right/justice'. Killed WITHOUT RIGHT - unjustly!
'Dhālika' = 'that'. Reiterates - THAT is why...
'Bimā' = 'because of what/due to what'. Another reason...
From ''aṣā' (to disobey). ''Aṣaw' = 'they disobeyed'. Disobedience to Allah's commands!

words.translation: And they were / And they used to

grammar.practical: 'Wa kānū' = 'and they were/used to'. Continuous state...

grammar.root: ع-د-و ('-d-w) - to transgress, to exceed limits
grammar.practical: From ''adā' (to exceed). Form VIII 'i'tadā' = to transgress, exceed limits. 'Ya'tadūna' = 'they transgress'. With kānū: 'they WERE (habitually) transgressing'. Pattern of continuous rebellion!

verses.arabic: إِنَّ ٱلَّذِينَ ءَامَنُوا۟ وَٱلَّذِينَ هَادُوا۟ وَٱلنَّصَٰرَىٰ وَٱلصَّٰبِـِٔينَ مَنْ ءَامَنَ بِٱللَّهِ وَٱلْيَوْمِ ٱلْءَاخِرِ وَعَمِلَ صَٰلِحًا فَلَهُمْ أَجْرُهُمْ عِندَ رَبِّهِمْ وَلَا خَوْفٌ عَلَيْهِمْ وَلَا هُمْ يَحْزَنُونَ
verses.transliteration: Inna alladhīna āmanū walladhīna hādū wan-naṣārā waṣ-ṣābi'īna man āmana billāhi wal-yawmi al-ākhiri wa 'amila ṣāliḥan falahum ajruhum 'inda rabbihim wa lā khawfun 'alayhim wa lā hum yaḥzanūn
verses.translation: Indeed, those who believed and those who were Jews or Christians or Sabeans - those [among them] who believed in Allah and the Last Day and did righteousness - will have their reward with their Lord, and no fear will there be concerning them, nor will they grieve

grammar.practical: 'Inna' = 'indeed/verily'. Strong emphasis on what follows - a universal principle!
'Alladhīna' = 'those who'. Starts listing groups...
From ''āmana' (to believe - Form IV). 'Āmanū' = 'they believed'. Refers to Muslims/believers in Muhammad ﷺ.
'Walladhīna' = 'and those who'. Second group...

grammar.root: ه-و-د (h-w-d) - to be Jewish, to return
grammar.practical: 'Hādū' = 'they were Jews/became Jewish'. From 'hāda' - refers to the Jews.
'Wan-naṣārā' = 'and the Christians'. Plural of naṣrānī. Third group!
'Waṣ-ṣābi'īn' = 'and the Sabeans'. Fourth group - an ancient religious community. The 'īna' ending is unusual here - grammatical nuance!
'Man' = 'whoever/who'. Specifies WHO among these groups - those WHO...
''Āmana' = 'he believed/has believed'. Condition: whoever BELIEVED...
'Billāhi' = 'in Allah'. Believed IN ALLAH - first requirement!
'Wal-yawm' = 'and the day'. Second requirement - belief in THE DAY...
'Al-ākhir' = 'the Last'. THE LAST DAY - the Day of Judgment!

grammar.root: ع-م-ل ('-m-l) - to do, to work, to act
grammar.practical: 'Wa 'amila' = 'and he did/worked'. Third requirement - DID...

grammar.root: ص-ل-ح (ṣ-l-ḥ) - to be righteous, to be good
grammar.practical: 'Ṣāliḥ' = 'righteous/good'. 'Ṣāliḥan' (accusative) = 'righteousness/righteous deeds'. Did RIGHTEOUS DEEDS. The three conditions: belief in Allah, belief in Last Day, righteous action!
'Falahum' = 'then for them/so for them'. Result: FOR THEM...
'Ajr' = 'reward'. 'Hum' = 'their'. Together: 'ajruhum' = 'their reward'. They have THEIR REWARD!

words.translation: With / At / In the presence of

grammar.practical: ''Inda' = 'with/at/in the sight of'. Their reward is WITH...
'Rabbihim' = 'their Lord'. Reward is WITH THEIR LORD - with Allah!
'Wa lā' = 'and no/not'. First promise...
'Khawf' = 'fear'. 'Khawfun' with tanwīn and nominative = 'fear' (as subject). NO FEAR - they won't fear!
''Alayhim' = 'upon them/for them'. No fear UPON THEM!
'Wa lā' = 'and not'. Second promise...
'Hum' = 'they'. Emphasis on subject.

grammar.root: ح-ز-ن (ḥ-z-n) - to grieve, to be sad
grammar.practical: From 'ḥazina' or 'ḥazana' (to grieve/be sad). 'Yaḥzanūna' = 'they grieve'. With 'lā': 'they will NOT grieve'. Beautiful verse: No fear about the future, no grief about the past!
